summary: This is a forwarded email from July 7, 2020, from an FBI New York CART Coordinator/Senior Forensic Examiner to an unspecified recipient, providing an update on the status of digital evidence in the Epstein case. It includes an attached spreadsheet and clarifies discrepancies in the evidence inventory, noting duplicate items and non-evidentiary materials collected.

persons.name: NYO CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.role: FBI Senior Forensic Examiner / CART Coordinator
persons.context: Author of the forwarded email, providing status on digital evidence processing for the Epstein case, clarifying inventory discrepancies and non-evidentiary items.

events.title: Epstein Evidence Status Update
events.description: An email was sent providing an update on the status of all digital evidence for the Epstein case, including clarifications on duplicate and non-evidentiary items.
personsInvolved: NYO CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

keyFacts: An Excel spreadsheet was attached detailing the status of all digital evidence in the Epstein case.
Several non-evidentiary items were included in the inventory to address a discrepancy of concern to the US Attorney's Office.
Nine hard drives collected from a New York apartment were actually only three unique drives, as three were duplicates of three others.
Several voice recorders were collected that CART (Computer Analysis Response Team) cannot process, and ten CDs were software install disks containing no user data.
The email clarifies that a previous status update only covered items the examiner had personally touched, not an exhaustive inventory of the case.
